conbody.p: Overview of the security features available with the Network Management Card (NMC) in the network monitoring system.

section.title: User Interface and Access Options
section.p: The NMC makes it possible to access the information from the Reality system remotely or locally.

The information can be accessed in different ways:
Graphical User Interface (GUI) also called the web interface, with remote access from a web browser.
Command Line Interface (CLI), with both local and remote access options.
Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) and Modbus, with both local and remote access options.
A proxy server cannot be used to access the NMC.

section.title: User Profiles and Access
section.p: To access the interface of the NMC a login with a user name and password is required. For higher security remote access can be managed by a Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) server.
The user name is case sensitive (maximum 64 American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) characters). There are five different user types:

li.p: Super User: Full access to all menus and options. Can add administrators.
Administrator: Full access to all menus and options.
Device Manager: Can only access the log options, event and UPS menu.
Read-Only User: Can view the same menus as the device manager, but can’t login to the CLI and can’t configure, delete data, or use file transfer options.
Network-Only User: Can only access the web interface and CLI remotely. Have access to network settings.

section.p: A user is automatically logged out after 3 minutes (default setting) of inactivity.

section.title: Password
section.p:
No password or passphrase is stored on the NMC as plain text.
The password is case sensitive (maximum 64 ASCII characters).
Passwords are hashed before they are stored using a one-way hash algorithm.
Passphrases used for authentication and encryption are encrypted before they are stored.
It is recommended to change the password after the first log-in and on a regular basis.

section.title: RADIUS Server
section.p: RADIUS is an authentication, authorization and accounting service. Used to centrally administer remote access individually for one or multiple NMC’s. With RADIUS each time a user tries to access the NMC, an authentication request is sent to the RADIUS server. Based on the user’s permission level the RADIUS server can accept, challenge or reject the request. With a RADIUS server a user can, for example, be allowed access if the user is signing in from the company network, but be denied access when trying to sign in with a Virtual Private Network (VPN). The RADIUS server can challenge a request by asking the user to provide a secondary password for example a PIN, token or card.

section.title: Connection Options and Network Protocols
section.p: The NMC supports remote and local connections via multiple standards with different security levels.
section.note: A protocol without encryption transmits information as plain text. Someone that monitors the network traffic can determine user names and passwords used to access the NMC interface.
section.p: Local access to the CLI uses a serial cable connection.

Remote access to the CLI can be established with:
Telnet
Secure Shell (SSH), encrypted

Remote access to the web interface can be established with:
Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS), encrypted, uses Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)

Other access options to the NMC are:
Simple Network Management Protocol v1 (SNMPv1)
Simple Network Management Protocol v3 (SNMPv3), encrypted
Modbus serial
Modbus 2-wired or 4-wired
Modbus Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)
If a Local Area Network (LAN) is used, there is an option to use the Extensible Authentication Protocol over LAN (EAPoL) protocol (IEEE 802.1X) for extra security.

section.title: Firmware
section.p:
Keep the firmware of the NMC updated to ensure that:
The NMC has the latest bug fixes and performance improvements.
The newest features can be used.
All NMC’s on the network have the same firmware version and support the same features in the same way.
There are multiple ways to update the firmware, all of them are secured with digital signature to make sure only verified firmware files can be used.

section.title: File Transfer
section.p:
File transfer is used both to update the firmware and to download data and event logs. There are two different protocols that can be used with different security options:
File Transfer Protocol (FTP): With FTP information is transferred as plain text. Use SCP for increased security.
Secure CoPy (SCP): With SCP the information transferred is encrypted. SCP is automatically used when the SSH protocol is enabled and configured and the FTP protocol is disabled.

section.title: Firewall
section.p:
A properly configured firewall is important part of network security. A firewall consists of a firewall policy that contains one or more rules. The configuration options for the rules are:
Priority: Set the priority of the rule. If two rules have a conflict the highest priority rule will decide. 1 is the highest priority and 250 the lowest.
IP/any: Select if the rule should apply to any IP address, a single IP address, a subnet address or a range of IP addresses.
Port: Specify what ports the rule should apply to.
Protocol: Specify what protocols the rule applies to.
Action: Defines if the firewall should allow or discard any packet that matches the rule.
When a firewall is active, each time a rule is applied to a packet (both blocked and allowed) it will be logged as an event. It is possible to view a log of the 50 most recent events.
If the firewall is used as an white list it is recommended to add a rule to block all other: 250 Dest any / Source any / protocol any / discard
If the firewall is used as an black list it is recommended to add a rule to allow all other: 250 Dest any / Source any / protocol any / allow

section.title: Digital Certificates
section.p:
For network communication that require higher security than password encryption it is possible to use digital certificates. This option is available from the web interface and the digital certificates use the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol. It is possible to use either a 1024-bit key or a 2048-bit key. There are three different methods for creating your digital certificate:
Method 1: Auto-generate a default certificate from the NMC.
Method 2: Use the APC Security Wizard to create a certificate authority and a server certificate.
Method 3: Use the APC Security Wizard to create a certificate-signing request that needs to be signed by the root certificate of an external (or your own) certificate authority and to create a server certificate.
